title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.6.29 | 24-11-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: DASYA GYANANJANI SHALAKAYA CHAKSHURUN MILITAM YENA TASMAI SHRI GURAVE NAMAHA
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: At the end of the millennium When the millennium The personality of Godhead Lord Narayana Lay down within the water of devastation Brahma began to enter into him Along with all creative elements And I also entered through his breathing
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verses to be discussed (SB 1.6.29-30) and explains the meaning of verse 29, focusing on Narada's experience at the end of a millennium.

segments.key_quote: Narada is not forced to take birth like us we are forced to take birth by laws of karma only because we have got residual reactions from the previous life or previous lives therefore we take birth and we are forced to take birth by the laws of karma
segments.summary: The speaker explains Prabhupada's purport, emphasizing the transcendental nature of Narada's birth and comparing it to the birth of Krishna, highlighting that pure devotees are not subject to karmic laws in the same way as ordinary beings.

segments.key_quote: The Lord and his devotees are therefore simultaneously one and different as spiritual entities.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the nature of pure devotees as spiritual entities, emphasizing their transcendence from material energy and their 'gunatita' state, while clarifying that they are distinct from God.

segments.key_quote: All these are transcendental appearance of the Lord. Similarly, transcendental appearance of Narada as the son of Brahma.
segments.summary: The speaker provides examples of transcendental appearances of the Lord (Rama, Vamana, Krishna) and reiterates that Narada's appearance is also transcendental, before introducing verse 30.

segments.key_quote: When Brahma's days over, at the beginning of Brahma's night, there is a partial devastation of the universe.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the process of partial devastation at the end of Brahma's day, the entering of living entities into Garbhodakshayi Vishnu, and the subsequent re-creation by Brahma, including the appearance of Narada and other rishis.

segments.key_quote: Brahma when the end of his day happens he rests in yoga nidra yoga nidra is not like our sleeping our sleeping is total ignorance we go into ignorance but Brahma's resting is just not in ignorance but it is in spiritual awareness that's called yoga nidra
segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining Brahma's day and night, emphasizing the concept of 'yoga nidra' and differentiating it from ordinary sleep, highlighting Brahma's continued spiritual awareness.

segments.key_quote: by the will of the Lord through the agency of Brahma all the great Rishis again appeared from different parts of the transcendental body and not also transcendental body and not also appears this is the pastime of the Lord creation
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Lord engages Brahma and other personalities in creation, maintenance, and destruction due to their desires, and reiterates the concept of yoga nidra.

segments.key_quote: Narada appears in the same transcendental body because Narada was awarded a transcendental body when he became perfect in devotional service he was awarded and he quit that previous body made of the five elements pancha bhautikam then he was awarded a transcendental body
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Brahma's yoga nidra with ordinary sleep, emphasizing that Brahma retains his form, and explains that Narada appears in the same transcendental body he was awarded after perfecting devotional service.

segments.key_quote: unlike conditioned beings we are conditioned so we are forced to take birth and die or quit the body whenever the the nature material nature forces us whereas Narada is not forced by material nature he is completely aloof from the influence of material nature
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the conditioned state of ordinary beings with Narada's liberated state, emphasizing his freedom from material nature and his ability to appear and disappear according to the Lord's will, before concluding the lecture.
